image.altText: Short sleeved dark navy police t-shirt, viewed from back of officer in uniform

items.synopsis: Earlier this year the Palaszczuk government introduced new youth just laws as part of a crackdown. Since the blitz began, the number of children charged with breach of bail can be revealed.

title.children: Dozens of juveniles charged with breach of bail in Queensland youth crime crackdown

image.altText: Jim Chalmers holds the budget while standing outside Parliament House

items.synopsis: The government has confirmed that tonight's federal budget will include an increase to the JobSeeker base rate, rent assistance, Austudy and Youth Allowance.

title.children: 'Help for the most vulnerable': JobSeeker increase confirmed in tonight's federal budget

image.altText: Katy Gallagher and Jim Chalmers walking past the budget tree

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers will deliver this year's federal budget, with a focus on cost of living and health. Follow live.

title.children: Treasurer set to announce billions in cost-of-living relief in this year’s federal budget

schema.headline: Federal budget live updates: Treasurer Jim Chalmers to announce billions in cost-of-living relief as part of 2023 budget

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Will the budget deliver on Medicare promises?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In healthcare, one of the big things to watch for tonight will be Medicare. The specialist reporting team's Penny Timms is here to help sort through it all: Penny: You might remember that last year, the federal government asked a team of experts to put their heads together and come up with recommendations on how to improve access to primary care and reduce the load on hospitals. Their Strengthening Medicare report, released in February, called for a rethink of how Australia funds primary care and GPs – but did not result in any immediate announcements. At the time, medical experts criticised the report for not including enough detail. So, a lot of people in healthcare will be looking out for the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce’s suggested reforms, and detail on how they will actually happen. The government has talked a big game, and if it doesn't do much, that is likely to be a talking point. During the election, Labor promised close to $1 billion for Medicare and GPs. Of that cash, $750 million was earmarked for the Strengthening Medicare scheme. Now the healthcare sector is waiting to see how it’s spent. One other area to watch is whether this budget will include funding for the promised Centre for Disease Control (CDC), which would better prepare Australia for national health emergencies. Last year’s October “mini-budget” included $3.2 million for “preparations to establish” the CDC. The government and health advocates have already flagged such a centre would require significant additional funding.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Finance Minister Katy Gallagher on what will be in the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal budget is set to include almost $15 billion in cost of living relief, amid a year where high inflation continues to take its toll. Speaking to ABC News Breakfast, Finance Minister Katy Gallagher said it's a "significant package". Kate Gallagher : Not just in the scale, but in the reach that we're trying to have with it. So, you know, you'll see different measures as part of that cost of living package. But I think what it shows is that, that really has been front and center our thinking as we finalise the budget... How to provide that sensible and affordable cost of living relief against, you know, an environment of high inflation and that's been certainly a challenge as we've been making our decisions, but people will see the full details of that.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: About 5 million households are expected to receive up to $500 in power bill relief in the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The support is expected to be aimed at pensioners, others on government payments and small businesses. The ABC's political reporter Tom Lowrey joins us, and says it's likely the relief will come in the form of subsidies on energy bills, as opposed to direct payments to households: Tom: For months the federal government has been talking up energy price relief as a “centrepiece” of the budget, and tonight they will finally put some detail to the rhetoric. $1.5bn was pledged in December to help Australians push their power bills down, which would be matched by the states and territories. It’s expected tonight’s package will see roughly five million households, and one million businesses, receive up to $500 in relief from their power bills. The support is expected to primarily be targeted at pensioners, others on government payments and small businesses. It’s also likely that rather than being paid directly to households, the relief will come as subsidies on energy bills. But the arrangements could become quite complex, as the federal government coordinates its package with various state and territory governments, and energy retailers.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: G'Day from budget lock-up
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hi everyone, Shiloh here! I've been sent off to the ABC's federal budget lockup. When you're reading this, I've probably already been locked in a room with no internet access for several hours, but don't worry, I'm not breaking any rules, I prepared this blog post for you earlier today. While Bridget is taking you through what we're expecting and what it will all mean for you, I'm trawling through the budget papers with a fine-tooth comb alongside a bunch of my colleagues. You'll hear from me throughout the blog, and I'll be bursting out of the lock-up at 7.30 pm to join you live and tell you everything there is to know about this year's budget.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Increase in JobSeeker and rent assistance confirmed ahead of tonight's federal budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In news just in, the government has confirmed that tonight's federal budget will include an increase to the JobSeeker base rate, rent assistance, Austudy and Youth Allowance. The JobSeeker payment currently sits at around $50 a day, while youth allowance is $40 a day. The government has promised a $14.6 billion cost-of-living relief package, targeting "the most vulnerable Australians". Earlier today, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said the relief is "broader than what has been speculated on." Chalmers: It has a number of elements, it won't all be limited by age or by other distinctions. There will be help for the most vulnerable, but also for middle Australia.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Welcome to our live coverage of the 2023 federal budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good afternoon and thanks for joining our live coverage of this year's federal budget. Very shortly I'll be joined by my blog co-hosts, Shiloh Payne, who'll have the latest out of lock-up, and business reporter Kate Ainsworth, who is here to help navigate what tonight's announcements mean for the economy, housing and more. Throughout this evening, we'll also hear from our team of political reporters in Canberra and journalists from across the country about what the budget means for you. At 7:30pm AEDT, you can watch the Treasurer's speech live using the stream at the top of the page. Until then, if you've got any questions or thoughts about this year's federal budget, use the blue Leave a Comment button above to send them in.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Watch the Treasurer's speech live at 7:30pm AEDT

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In healthcare, one of the big things to watch for tonight will be Medicare. The specialist reporting team's Penny Timms is here to help sort through it all: Penny: You might remember that last year, the federal government asked a team of experts to put their heads together and come up with recommendations on how to improve access to primary care and reduce the load on hospitals. Their Strengthening Medicare report, released in February, called for a rethink of how Australia funds primary care and GPs – but did not result in any immediate announcements. At the time, medical experts criticised the report for not including enough detail. So, a lot of people in healthcare will be looking out for the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce’s suggested reforms, and detail on how they will actually happen. The government has talked a big game, and if it doesn't do much, that is likely to be a talking point. During the election, Labor promised close to $1 billion for Medicare and GPs. Of that cash, $750 million was earmarked for the Strengthening Medicare scheme. Now the healthcare sector is waiting to see how it’s spent. One other area to watch is whether this budget will include funding for the promised Centre for Disease Control (CDC), which would better prepare Australia for national health emergencies. Last year’s October “mini-budget” included $3.2 million for “preparations to establish” the CDC. The government and health advocates have already flagged such a centre would require significant additional funding.

image.altText: A woman in a police uniform standing in front of a microphone next to a man in a blue shirt

items.synopsis: In an effort to bolster Queensland's police numbers, a new recruitment drive will offer a "significant increase" in wages and help you pay off some of your HECS debt.

title.children: First-year police constables will earn six figures for a 38-hour week in new recruitment drive

image.altText: An aerial view of a large crowd, with blurring as of the camera spinning.

items.synopsis: Australians are buying significantly fewer goods at shops and department stores, new Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) data show.

title.children: 'It is here': Official data confirms Australia in a 'consumer recession'

image.altText: A man holding his phone and walking down the stairs outside a courthouse.

items.synopsis: A jury has found a Van Dung Vu, 37, not guilty of possessing 2.5kg of heroin found in a package of disposable gloves destined for a North Queensland nail salon, with his defence barrister saying he was scammed.

title.children: Baker found not guilty after 2.5kg shipment of heroin delivered to nail salon

image.altText: Shane walks along carrying documents and wearing sunglasses.

items.synopsis: ACT Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold called police officers investigating the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins "boofheads", Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer tells an inquiry.

title.children: ACT top prosecutor allegedly labelled police investigators 'boofheads' during Bruce Lehrmann's trial

image.altText: ice being lifted out of a bird bath

items.synopsis: Queenslanders are shivering before winter has even arrived, with inland regions recording their coldest May morning on record.

title.children: 'It's thongs-and-socks cold': Queensland shivers through coldest May morning on record

image.altText: A blue sign with white writing on a building that reads "Jenny Craig".

items.synopsis: Administrators have been appointed to oversee operations for Jenny Craig Australia and New Zealand less than a week after the US company filed for bankruptcy.

title.children: Jenny Craig Australia enters voluntary administration after US business files for bankruptcy

image.altText: Tom Seymour in a suit and a tie speaking on stage at the AFR Summit.

items.synopsis: PricewaterhouseCoopers Australia chief executive Tom Seymour stands down as the consulting firm feels the fallout of a partner betraying the trust of its biggest client: the federal government.

title.children: PwC CEO steps down after tax documents leak scandal

image.altText: View from inside a car of a flooded road.

items.synopsis: Schools are evacuated, roads and parks are flooded and people are being told to prepare to leave homes in case of flash flooding around New Zealand.

title.children: Student missing in a cave as Auckland declares state of emergency

image.altText: A girl, Alyssa, whose face is blurred, leans on a car in a relaxed way.

items.synopsis: Child safety departments knowingly leave some children with carers who have had serious concerns raised about them, insiders say. In some states, foster and kinship carers don't even have a working with children check.

title.children: Alyssa said 'yes' to four-wheel driving with her foster brother. Then the abuse started

image.altText: A picture of pedestrians walking over a bridge in Melbourne

items.synopsis: One of the world's foremost experts on cities has warned Australia risks "sleepwalking into a long-term loss of productivity"  but not everyone agrees.

title.children: Australian cities are falling behind the rest of the world when it comes to productivity. Here's why

image.altText: People in masks walk past a Westpac building in a city.

items.synopsis: Months after postponing the closures because of an ongoing Senate inquiry, the bank has announced that branches in several states will remain open indefinitely.

title.children: Westpac reverses decision to close eight regional branches

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2023-24 federal budget strategy and outlook book in front of the media

items.synopsis: These major budget measures reveal the type of plan the federal government has for Australia, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: What's in the budget? Here are some of the major measures we know about

image.altText: Row of large homes along waterfront with boats moored out front

items.synopsis: Two of Queensland's most sought-after regions have an estimated 10,000 properties locked up as short-stay accommodation, but affordable housing advocates say holiday lets are not the driving force behind the rental shortage.

title.children: Why Airbnbs and short-stays don't deserve all the blame for Noosa rental shortage

image.altText: A black and white pamphlet saying "you and your loved ones are at risk of prescription medicine shortages".

items.synopsis: Patients say they are distressed and disappointed after receiving calls warning of prescription medicine shortages "due to the Albanese Labor government".

title.children: 'Anxiety and mayhem': Pharmacy Guild draws fire over robocalls to 'very vulnerable patients'

image.altText: A high rise building at Mermaid Beach on the Gold Coast

items.synopsis: A crime scene has been established at Mermaid Beach property where an infant has been found dead.

title.children: Police investigate death of baby girl on Gold Coast

image.altText: A photo of Heather Winchester and her husband John, with their heads touching sitting on couch.

items.synopsis: A Hunter Valley woman has told an inquest her Jehovah's Witness mother was acting on what the church wanted her to do by refusing a blood transfusion that could have saved her life.

title.children: Woman tells inquest her Jehovah's Witness mother refused potentially life-saving blood transfusion

image.altText: A man sits at a desk and signs a paper

items.synopsis: The owner of a high-end jeweller in Sydney's CBD is charged with defrauding an insurance company after he allegedly orchestrated his own store's robbery at knifepoint.

title.children: Famous jeweller masterminded robbery on his own Sydney store, police allege

image.altText: A woman checks her mobile phone as she walks past Telstra signage

items.synopsis: Telstra says some of its mobile customers are still having trouble making phone calls, after an earlier outage which affected mobile networks in NSW and Queensland.

title.children: Telstra says outages in NSW and Queensland weren't caused by cyber attack

image.altText: The drug Xanax

items.synopsis: Queensland Health say tablets tested positive for protoniteazene, an extremely dangerous and potentially life-threatening opioid that can be fatal, even in small amounts.

title.children: Spiked counterfeit pills may be linked to two deaths, Queensland police say

image.altText: Image of a person outside court in Perth. Their face is blurred and they are wearing a black suit jacket with a white shirt.

items.synopsis: A former physical education teacher who sexually abused a teenage student at a WA school more than a decade ago is jailed, with the judge noting the "significant power imbalance" and the ongoing impact on the victim.

title.children: 'She idolised you': Female teacher jailed over sexual abuse of 16-year-old student

image.altText: A man in a grey and white suit surrounded by photographers

items.synopsis: Sam Bankman-Fried, who has long denied stealing from customers of his FTX cryptocurrency exchange, asks a US judge to throw out criminal charges against him over the now-bankrupt FTX's collapse.

title.children: 'A rush to judgement': FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried urges court to toss charges

image.altText: Two men with backs to the camera lean up against fence looking at cattle

items.synopsis: There's dust in the air, dirt on the boots, and the booming voices of auctioneers break through the cattle-dung-scented air, but farmers don't want to let go of saleyards despite the boom in online sales.

title.children: Social power of saleyards 'like a men's shed, but not just for men'

image.altText: a man wearing glasses talking to the press outdoors

items.synopsis: Ben Franklin nominates himself for the position a day after state party leader Paul Toole is booted out in a leadership spill.

title.children: Franklin defies own party to secure plum NSW upper house president job

image.altText: A close up of Dame Edna complete with her iconic sunglasses and purple hair.

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirms Barry Humphries's family has chosen Sydney as the city for the entertainer's service, despite him being born in Melbourne.

title.children: Barry Humphries to be farewelled in Sydney instead of home city Melbourne

image.altText: A man in water gear stands on a wooden jetty with a paddle board behind him and an oar in his hands.

items.synopsis: In a "hair-brained" journey of more than 2,500km down the Murray River on just his stand-up paddleboard, Peter Charlesworth's aim is for regional Australians to take their heart health seriously.

title.children: Peter is paddling an epic 2,642km, with no support crew, on a board he's meaningfully named 'Karina'

image.altText: John Farnham singing into a microphone.

items.synopsis: The 73-year-old was taken to hospital in March with a respiratory infection, and has been recovering from surgery to treat cancer.

title.children: Singer John Farnham makes 'full recovery' from chest infection that left him hospitalised

image.altText: A side view of a saltwater crocodile on a river bank with its eye open

items.synopsis: Employing sonars and artificial intelligence, the warning system is expected to be installed at busy boat ramps as part of a suite of measures to reduce the risk of crocodile attacks in the state.

title.children: Crocodile detection devices to be rolled out in parts of Queensland in wake of fatal attack

image.altText: Charles and Camilla stand with other members of the working royal family.

items.synopsis: King Charles has given "sincere and heartfelt" thanks to everyone involved in his coronation weekend, as Buckingham Palace releases the first official portraits of the new monarch.

title.children: Who are the working royals? A who's who as first official portrait of Charles as King released
